post_info.post_title: How will Martha's convictions (4) affect you?

Aside from a small snicker every time I think about her cheating, lying, white, rich butt in jail, it won't. :p

I hear stripes will be the pattern of choice this year for window curtains.
 
 
 Seriously though it goes to show you how the government can go after you for ANYTHING... Do you really think that stuart was even aware of such a small amount? If she was she is a XXXXX but still sounds fishy to me...

 'Tis the season for moral/righteous indignation and rewarding jealousy by following the law to the letter; government careers in the prosecution of tycoons and others are there to be made. Government; our fastest growing industry.

Pointless publicity stunt to quell fears surrounding the Enron scandal. It will have ZERO effect on diminishing the type of trading she was convicted of.
 
 Poor Martha is nothing more than a government fall guy. She took a rap for a practice that is as common as saying good morning in the business community. 
 
 You're a fool if you don't have your ear to the ground and aren't willing to act on it.
 
 Victory for the little guy my arse.

 People trade (buy and sell) stocks every day. There is nothing illegal about that. But when you seek, recieve, and act on inside information, you are breaking the law. She got caught, she got convicted, she deserves to pay the penalty. So does anyone else breaking the law in such manner, regardless of who they are or who there friends are.

 Ignorance of the law is not an applicable defense. I would say the fact that she attempted to cover it up pretty much reduces any doubt as to whether or not she knew it was illegal.

 STU

Let me ask you this what do you think they will do about Ken Lay and all of the other Enron goodbuddys?

 
 I don't pretend to make predicitions about what they will do, but as far as what I hope they do...I hope they go after them with the gloves off and send them all to prison. Rich people that feel the need to steal and cheat people who are already barely keeping their heads above water, all in the name of becoming more rich, are nauseating. I hope heads roll. This will be dealt with in a court of law, not in the Whitehouse as many left-wing spin doctors will have you believe.

The Enron and the WorldCom people did a lot more damage to society than Martha did.
 
 They should all be prosecuted to the fullest extent of the law and should get maximum sentences for ruining the lives of thousands of people.
 
 But you know, they could get Presidential Pardons like Clinton's buddies did when he left office. What a creep Slick Willy IS!

 Sundowner: I will be very surprised if they do get convicted what they did was despicable. A lot of people worked all there years for a nest egg to only have it robbed from them. Alot of those folks are not enjoying there golden years because of that. Not to talk about all of the other **** they pulled off.

 Jim, Martha, Enron, Worldcom, Tyco, etc., etc. should all get the exact amount of punishment they deserve under the laws that were in place when they broke them. No more, no less: wealth should have no bearing on their punishment or how they are prosecuted.
 
 Now as for the Clinton pardons, what does that have to do with the price of beans? That perogative has been available to presidents by law. If we don't like the law, we should change it. Otherwise, what's the point of getting offended when they use it?? I'm not for the pardons, but they were legal before Clinton.
